div.head:
Embleme 43. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Give ear to the Vultur'sVulture's words, which are weewenoewise false.

lg.l: The weeweVultur on the weewemountaine stands in sight,
Himselfe proclaiming daily, weeweblacke, and white,
Citrine, and red; nor false: The Raven is
The same, which without wings by nature weeweflyes
In dismalldismal weewedarkenesse, and in glorious light,
For either will to th'the art conduct you right.

div.head: Discourse 43.
div.ab:
Wee daily in many places hear birds prattling or imitating the weewevoyce
of man, such as ParrottsParrots, Ravens, Dawes, and PyesPies. SoeSo Pliny writes-
that, at the time wherein weewehee published his history, Agrippina the-
wife of Claudius CæsarCaesar had a thrush, imitating the speech of men.-
The young CæsarsCaesars had weeweallso a Starling and Nightingales accustomed to
the GreekeGreek and LatineLatin tongue, and daily speaking new things, with-
a long weeweforme of words weeweallso. But such birds now frequently happening
they are thought weewelesse worthy of admiration, for all birds endu'dendued-
with a broad tongue may by use and weewecustome be brought to weewespeake
and babble. But that weeweVultur, which the Philosophers make mention
of, did not weewelearne words, if any weewehee utters, by use, but his nature tacit
ly expressethexpresses them. The Philosophers weewedoe indeed say, that weewehee-
continually weewecryes out, and with a loud weeweVoyce pronouncethpronounces, who and
what weewehee is, wherein weewehee imitates great Princes, who in the weewebegining
of their intimations will weeweallwayes make their titles and inheritances-
knowne, not in token of any pride, but for other reasons, that they-
allso themselves may know, what principalityesprincipalies they weewegoverne, or-
right of inheritance they prætendpretend to: SoeSo it is very weewemateriall to-
know, what weewecolours, as ensigns of weewearmes and titles, the weewePhilosophi
call bird is adorndadorned with, and wherein weewehee excellsexcels all others. I, weeweSayth weewehee,
as Rosarius weewehath it from Hermes, am the weeweblacke of white, and the ci
trine of red, and certainly I weewespeake truth and weewelye not. weeweHee weeweaffirmes
himselfe blacke, white, citrine, and red, and such weewehee really is, for-
though weewehee weewedoth not as yet actually possessepossess the last weewecolours, yet weewehee
expects the inheritance of them: Hereupon weeweSayth Rosinus in his weewebooke
of divine interpretations; Take the Stone, which is weeweblacke, white,-
red, citrine, that admirable bird, which weeweflyes without wings in the
darknesse of the night, and clearnesseclearness of the day: For coloration-
arisetharises from the bitternessebitterness which is in his throat, but mere water-
proceeds from his blood, as Alexander weewesayd. Take (My weeweSonne) the
Stone of four weewecolours. The Philosophers books weewedoe abundantly de
clare and insinuate that the Stone weewehath all these weewecolours, which
are weeweprincipall, in a successive order. But why the weewePhilosophicall
subject is weewecalld a weeweVultur, there is reason to be alleadgedalleged. Of weeweVulturs-
the weeweblacke are of most esteem, they are rapacious, but fly Slowly, be
cause of the weewebignesse of body. They say that this bird conceives-
without the seed of the males, and generates without coition, and
that their offspring weewedoe arrive to a great age even to a hundred-
years. Their nests they build in high rocks, weewenoe man weewehath attained
to them. Two chickens are for the most part seen: They are weewehelpe
full and commodious weeweagaynst Serpents. They are offended and-
Discourse 43.
perplexed with the East wind. When they begin to lay eggs, they-
bring a thing out of the weeweIndyes, which is as a nuttnut, having within a-
thing that may be moved, and forthwith weeweyeild a sound, which when
they have weeweapplyed to them, they produce many young chickens,-
but one weeweonely remaynsremains, which is weewecalld Immusulus. Hermodorus Fon
ticus in CæliusCaelius is a weewewittnesse, that weeweVulturs of all weeweanimalls are the-
most innocent, because they weewedoe not at all meddle with any of those
things which men sow, plant, and breed. Moreover they kill weewenoe-
animalls. They weeweallso weeweabstaine from birds though dead by a weewecertaine
instinct of affinity: For this cause they were best weeweesteemd in divina
tions, as the weeweoriginalls of the CittyCity of Rome declare. The weewePhiloso
phicall bird expressing weeweallmost all these weewepropertyes of weeweVulturs, is
therefore by Hermes and others not undeservedly called weeweVultur, which
is weeweallso slow in flight, and weeweblacke of weewecolour; It conceives by weeweitselfe:
For thus weewesayth Rosarius about the end; And it is the Dragon, which
weddsweds weeweitselfe, and impregnatsimpregnates weeweitselfe, and brings forth in its weeweowne
season Ct. And Rosinus to Sarratant: And that is the Serpent, weewead
ministring pleasure to weeweitselfe, impregnating weeweitselfe, and bringing
forth in one day, Ct. It lives and endures a very long time, and-
multiplyes weeweitselfe. For that which VirgillVirgil writes of the bird weewecalld
a PhænixPhoenix, is as proper to this, because it is the same.
Alipedem Cervum Corvus ter vincit, at illum
Multiplicat novies PhænixPhoenix reparabilis abes.
Three ages of a Hart the Raven lives,
Which the rare PhænixPhoenix nine times o'reover survives.
It is very difficult to weeweclimbe this birds nest: It fights with the weeweMercuriall
serpent, and overcomes it, that is, Sol with Luna. It is conceived by-
the wind, and weewecarryed in its belly, and bred in the weeweaire. The-
Stone ÆlitesElites, containing a little stone sounding within it is by many
men called Totium. One weeweonely Immusulus is found in the Philoso
phers nest. The weewePhilosophicke bird is weeweallso most innocent, because
it hurts weewenoe body, it is weewebeneficiall to all that know it, and most ex
cellent in divinations. But why weewedoth it make its nest on a weeweMountaine,
and sitting soeso cry out? Rosinus answers according to Rasis, who weewesayth.
Behold the most high mountains, which are both on the right and
left, and weeweclimbe up thither: There is our Stone found, and in another
mountaine, which producethproduces all sorts of Painter weewecolours, and Spirits-
or Species, there likewise it is: Morienus: weeweClimbe up the high mountains,
planted wih trees, because there is our stone found, and hidden: And Hermes:
Take yee the blessed Stone, weewebreake it to weewepeices, and wash the red stone, from
which is extracted that which is found in mountains, and especially sometimes in old Sinks.
